Description: Neck of a blown glass unguentarium or flask (body missing, but probably of the 'candlestick' type with a baggy or triangular shape); tall, narrow cylindrical neck, splaying outwards towards the base; the only part of the body preserved is a small piece projecting from the base of the neck; slight constriction at base of neck where it met the body; everted horizontal rim (folded upward and inward, and pressed down on top of neck); contains considerable quantity of light-coloured grease or fatty residue, as well as what appears to be the original sealant in the upper neck.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Curium
Curator's comments: Parallels: G. McFadden 1946, 'A tomb of the necropolis of Ayios Ermoyenis at Kourion', AJA 50, 449-89, pl. XLIV, 98-105 (Tomb 8, chamber); SCE IV/3, 163-4 and figs 49-50 passim. ('Unguentarium of candlestick type'); also J. Hayes 1975, Roman and pre-Roman glass in the Royal Ontario Museum. A catalogue, Ontario, pp. 125-30. Hayes notes that these examples may be either or Syrian or Cypriot in origin as the precise place of manfacture is uncertain in many cases.
